Agents.Display: Ballantine, Henry (1846-1914, American) collector|Rau, William Herman (American photographer, 1855-1920) publisher

Notes.Display: Title from handwritten caption label attached to slide. Printed on label: William H. Rau & Co., 1206 Chestnut St., Philadelphia.|Born in Ahmednagar, India, the son of a Christian missionary, Henry Ballantine graduated from Amherst College in 1868 then returned to India where he was a merchant in Bombay from 1870-1872. Ballantine traveled to the Himalayas and Nepal in 1885 and 1888, and he also served as U.S. Consul to India from 1891-1896. During this time, he collected and took photographs and wrote about his travels in a book, On India's frontier, or, Nepal, the Ghurkas' mysterious land (1896).|2684 (Ballantine’s slide number)

Note.term: Title from handwritten caption label attached to slide. Printed on label: William H. Rau & Co., 1206 Chestnut St., Philadelphia.

Born in Ahmednagar, India, the son of a Christian missionary, Henry Ballantine graduated from Amherst College in 1868 then returned to India where he was a merchant in Bombay from 1870-1872. Ballantine traveled to the Himalayas and Nepal in 1885 and 1888, and he also served as U.S. Consul to India from 1891-1896. During this time, he collected and took photographs and wrote about his travels in a book, On India's frontier, or, Nepal, the Ghurkas' mysterious land (1896).

ssn:Name.preferredTerm: Harvard Fine Arts Library, Special Collections

Term.name: Harvard Fine Arts Library, Special Collections

Note.noteText: Eloise Sager Bettge collection : photographs by Raja Deen Dayal and other materials related to Henry Ballantine on deposit from Rowe Kaple.

Born in Ahmednagar, India, the son of a Christian missionary, Henry Ballantine graduated from Amherst College in 1868 then returned to India where he was a merchant in Bombay from 1870-1872. He later served as U.S. Consul there from 1891-1896.

Biography.name: American photographer; born Philadelphia (Pennsylvania, United States), 1855; died Philadelphia (Pennsylvania, United States), 1920

birthPlace.name: Philadelphia (Philadelphia county, Pennsylvania, United States) (inhabited place)

deathPlace.name: Philadelphia (Philadelphia county, Pennsylvania, United States) (inhabited place)

ScopeNote.ScopeNoteText: Born 19 January 1855; died 19 November 1920. In 1874 Rau obtained a position with the United States Government Expedition to document the transit of Venus. In 1877 he formed a partnership with his father-in-law William Bell, a survey photographer. Rau purchased Bell's stereograph company in 1877, and operated it under his own name until it was purchased by Underwood and Underwood in 1901. In 1881 Rau photographed in Colorado and New Mexico. He also travelled to Egypt to photograph monuments in the 1880s. Rau was appointed in 1890 as the official photographer of the Pennsylvania Railroad, and appointed in 1895 as the official photographer of the LeHigh Valley Railroad to document views along their lines. Rau also photographed the Johnstown, Pennsylvania flood and the 1904 Baltimore fire. He was associated with the Photographic Society of Philadelphia, the American Lantern Slide Interchange, the Photographic Exchange Club of Philadelphia and the Detroit Publishing Company. American landscape photographer, Philadelphia.

aat:AAT.englishScopeNote: Refers to still images produced from radiation-sensitive materials (sensitive to light, electron beams, or nuclear radiation), generally by means of the chemical action of light on a sensitive film, paper, glass, or metal. It does not include reproductive prints of documents and technical drawings, for which descriptors found under "<reprographic copies>" are more appropriate. Photographs may be positive or negative, opaque or transparent.

ScopeNote.notesText: Niet bewegende afbeeldingen vervaardigd met van stralingsgevoelige materialen (gevoelig voor licht, elektronenstralen of nucleaire straling), met uitzondering van reproductieve afdrukken van documenten en technische tekeningen. Gebruik daarvoor termen, die bijeengebracht zijn onder 'reprografische kopieën'. Foto's kunnen positief of negatief zijn, ondoorschijnend of transparant (in vaktermen: opzicht of doorzicht).

Contributor.fullName: Bureau AAT, RKD (Netherlands Institute for Art History; The Hague, The Netherlands)

ScopeNote.notesText: Se refiere a imágenes fijas producidas por materiales sensibles a la radiación (sensibles a la luz, rayos de electrones o radiación nuclear), generalmente por medio de la acción química de la luz sobre una película, papel, vidrio o metal sensible. No incluye impresiones de documentos reproductivos y dibujos técnicos, para los cuales los descriptores que se encuentran bajo "<copias reprográficas>" son más apropiados. Las fotografías pueden ser en positivo o negativo, opacas o transparentes.

Contributor.fullName: Centro de Documentación de Bienes Patrimoniales (Dirección de Bibliotecas, Archivos y Museos; Santiago, Chile)

ScopeNote.notesText: Het onderscheid tussen dorp, gemeente en stad is betrekkelijk en varieert naar gelang de individuele, regionale context. Kleine steden zijn meestal compacte nederzettingen, die groter zijn dan een dorp, maar minder belangrijk en complex dan de grote steden in de regio.

Contributor.fullName: Bureau AAT, RKD (Netherlands Institute for Art History; The Hague, The Netherlands)

ScopeNote.notesText: Distinciones entre aldeas, pueblos y ciudades son relativas y varían según su contexo regional individual. Por lo general, los pueblos son unidades de asentamiento compacto mayores que las aldeas, pero menos importantes y menos complejas internamente que las ciudades en la región.

tgn:TGN.tgn:Note: Town acquired from Raja of Sikkim & developed as sanatorium for English soldiers 1835; name means "place of the thunderbolt"; noted for Mount Everest, zoo, museum of natural history, racecourse & hospitals; connected by air to Calcutta.
